'''Boyne Castle''' is a [[16th-century]] [[quadrangular castle]] about {{convert|1.5|mi}} east of [[Portsoy]], [[Aberdeenshire]], [[Scotland]], {{convert|0.5|mi}} south of Boyne Bay.<ref name=Coventry>Coventry, Martin (2001). ''The Castles of Scotland''. Musselburgh: Goblinshead. p. 87 ISBN 1-899874-26-7</ref>
==History==
Around 1320 the land was owned by [[Thomas Randolph, 1st Earl of Moray]], but passed first to the Edmonstone family and then, by marriage, to the [[Clan Ogilvy|Ogilvies]]. Sir George Ogilvy of Dunlugas built the castle in the late 16th century. Occupation continued until after 1723.<ref name=Coventry/>
==Structure== The site of Boyne castle is naturally fortified, above the steep gorge of the Burn of Boyne,<ref name="British Listed Buildings">{{cite web |url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/sc-39-boyne-castle-boyndie#.V7w7smdRHL8|title=Boyne Castle |publisher=[[British Listed Buildings]]|accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref> or Boyne Water, which protects it on three sides, while on the south there is a dry moat, nearly {{convert|60|ft}} wide.<ref name=Canmore/>
It has been said that Boyne Castle “was once a splendid place with fine rooms, above vaulted basements, and had large windows”. The remains are overgrown and ruinous, <ref name=Coventry/> although the walls to the west, and the towers, still stand to about {{convert|33|ft}}.<ref name=Canmore>{{cite web |url=https://canmore.org.uk/site/18436/boyne-castle|title=Boyne Castle |publisher=[[Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Scotland]] |accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref>
The four corner towers are round, and about {{convert|22|ft}} in diameter.<ref name=Canmore/> There is a twin-turreted gatehouse<ref name=Coventry/> to the south.<ref name=Canmore/> Entrance is by a causeway, which is raised and walled.<ref name=Coventry/>
There are remains of two walled gardens.<ref name=Coventry/>
It is a Category A Listed Building.<ref name="British Listed Buildings"/>
